title: New book: Machine Learning in Survival Analysis
text: My online textbook Machine Learning in Survival Analysis, co-authored with Raphael Sonabend, is now available at mlsabook.com. The book is a work in progress — feedback and suggestions, issues and PRs are very welcome in our open GitHub repository

title: New project: Menstrual Blood Analysis with AI
text:
We started the Menstrual Blood AI project, exploring menstrual blood as a non-invasive diagnostic tool using AI. The project targets early detection of endometriosis, diabetes, and cancer biomarkers — aiming to reduce the 7–10 year diagnostic delay for endometriosis.
Project page

title: New publication: Flexible modelling of time-varying exposures and recurrent events
text:
Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series C: Applied Statistics
A flexible modelling approach to analyse time-varying exposures and recurrent events in team sports injuries, based on the piece-wise exponential additive mixed model. The effects of past high-intensity training loads may accumulate over time, and a penalty approach is proposed to identify the relevant time window at which past exposures impact current risk.
Find paper on Google Scholar

title: Andreas Bender
text:
Head Machine Learning Consulting Unit (MLCU) Munich Center for Machine Learning (MCML) LMU Munich
I am the head of the Machine Learning Consulting Unit (MLCU) at the Munich Center for Machine Learning and Senior Lecturer at the Department of Statistics at LMU Munich.
My research focuses on statistical and machine learning methods for non-standard data with correlations (hierarchical, longitudinal, spatial) and complex temporal processes with sampling bias and partial observability (survival analysis).
I’m passionate about scientific consulting and knowledge transfer into domain science and industry.

title: Projects
text:
pammtools
R package for fitting and analyzing piece-wise exponential additive mixed models (PAMMs) for survival analysis. Flexible modeling of time-varying effects, cumulative effects, and competing risks.
Documentation | CRAN | GitHub





mlr3proba
R package extending the mlr3 ecosystem for probabilistic predictions and survival analysis. Unified interface for survival learners, measures, and prediction types.
Documentation | GitHub





Menstrual Blood AI
Exploring menstrual blood as a non-invasive diagnostic tool using AI. Targeting early detection of endometriosis, diabetes, and cancer biomarkers from an underutilized biological resource.
Project page





Machine Learning in Survival Analysis
Online textbook co-authored with Raphael Sonabend covering machine learning methods for survival analysis. Includes theory, worked examples in R, and practical guidance for practitioners.
Read online





coalitions
R package for Bayesian estimation of coalition probabilities in multi-party democracies. Combines survey data with MCMC sampling to estimate seat distributions and coalition scenarios.
Documentation | CRAN | GitHub






CODAG — COVID-19 Data Analysis Group
Collaborative research initiative at LMU Munich analyzing COVID-19 infection data, disease progression, and resource demand forecasting. Joint effort of the Institute for Statistics, the Institute for Medical Informatics, Biometrics and Epidemiology, and LMU’s Data Science Initiative.
Project page

title: New publication: Predictive modeling for step II therapy response in periodontitis
text:
npj Digital Medicine
Machine learning models were developed to predict changes in periodontal probing depth after step II therapy using patient-, tooth-, and site-specific clinical covariates. While predictive performance based on routine clinical data remains limited, models can stratify periodontal sites into meaningful categories and estimate the probability of pocket improvement.
Find paper on Google Scholar

title: New publication: Deep generative models in digital subtraction angiography (DSA)
text:
Artificial Intelligence Review
Deep generative models such as GANs, VAEs, and diffusion models have demonstrated remarkable success in static medical imaging tasks. This systematic review synthesizes 20 peer-reviewed studies published between 2018 and 2025, offering a comprehensive analysis of generative model usage in angiographic imaging, covering tasks such as image generation, vessel segmentation, and stenosis detection.
Find paper on Google Scholar
